Once Russia passed legislation threatening up to 15 years in prison for publishing ‚Äúfake‚Äù information about the invasion of Ukraine, independent news editor Taisia Bekbulatova was forced to frantically evacuate her Russia-based staff to ensure their safety and freedom.

Viktoria Roschina, a reporter with the independent Ukrainian television station @HromadskeUA, was held hostage for 10 days by Russian forces.

They forced her to record a video denying being detained and later posted it on pro-Russian media and social media outlets.

Russian forces abducted and held Iryna Dubchenko in custody after searching her home because of her ‚Äújournalistic activities.‚Äù

They accused her of hiding a wounded Ukrainian soldier and took her to Donetsk for ‚Äúinvestigative action."

April's ‚Äú10 Most Urgent‚Äù list from @OneFreePress features journalists covering the war in #Ukraine. 

Journalists face exile, death and risking their lives to present the facts and the human toll of this invasion. Read about their cases here: https://t.co/aqyzq6ujKS üßµ https://t.co/hGtUbamQPH

How to find a mentor? @JasmineMonet_ and @TonyaMosley say: Just ask! Don't be afraid to cold email or reach out on social media ‚Äì people want to help and if you show interest, they'll show it back!

"Throughout my life, those who have guided me and held my hand have been women of color. When the opportunity to be a mentor through the Gwen Ifill program came up, I jumped at the chance, because mentors have been imperative to my career in journalism." ‚Äì @TonyaMosley

Afghan anchor #MinaKhairi was killed in June after attackers detonated an improvised explosive device attached to a van. 

No one has been held accountable for her murder. #Afghanistan ranks 5th on @pressfreedom's 2021 Impunity Index.

Police in India filed a criminal complaint against columnist @RanaAyyub, alleging a tweet she posted was unverified.
 
This persecution is not new ‚Äî Ayyub has long been the target of harassment and misinformation campaigns in response to her commentary and reporting.

Radio reporter @AprilEhrlich was arrested in Oregon while covering evictions of people living in a city park. After being released, she was charged with multiple misdemeanors.
 
These charges and police policies forfeit journalists‚Äô ability to cover critical stories without fear.

#ZhangZhan is critically ill in China yet still being held in detention.

She went on a hunger strike in prison after being sentenced for ‚Äúprovoking trouble‚Äù by criticizing the government‚Äôs COVID-19 response. 

#China is the worst jailer of journalists worldwide.

This month's @OneFreePress ‚Äú10 Most Urgent‚Äù list presents ‚Äúthe year in press freedom.‚Äù 

The cases encompass threats against journalists for pursuing and reporting the truth‚Äîfrom impunity to imprisonment.

For journos facing attacks online: feel frustrated, because you deserve to be frustrated. But know this is not reflective of your value or your work‚Äôs value, share @amrothom
and Dr. Raghavan. 

(BTW ‚Äì if you're experiencing threats online, we can help: https://t.co/4Si8z09Pdx)

"You can do a better job of your work if you take care of yourself." Don't let the "shoulds" get in your way ‚Äì you don't have to feel guilty if you can't take on the story, emphasize Dr. Raghavan and @amrothom on our webinar.

"We don‚Äôt have to just cover trauma and sadness ‚Äì #journalists of color can cover good, fluffy stories too. It‚Äôs okay. You don‚Äôt have to be pigeon-holed into suffering." A necessary reminder from @amrothom.

Dr. Raghavan suggests using the "BDA" technique when taking on a traumatic assignment.

Before: Check in with yourself for signs of stress ‚Äì it‚Äôs ok to say no.

During: Focus on the task at hand. Breathe, take breaks.

After: Find some safety. Regroup and recoup. https://t.co/IKKdtaRGtC

"Vicarious trauma isn‚Äôt a flood, it‚Äôs a drip. It builds up." On our webinar, Dr. Sumi Raghavan emphasizes that checking in with yourself and your behavior can help you notice when you‚Äôre hitting your limit.

When deciding whether to take on a story about racial injustice, @amrothom asks herself:
1) Is the pay worth it?
2) Is it a topic I enjoy?
3) Will this story propel my career?
4) How will it impact my emotional health?

‚ÄúI want to validate that experience. If you‚Äôre a journalist of color covering these conflicts and feeling the weight of it, that‚Äôs real. The science backs it up.‚Äù Vicarious trauma for journos reporting on trauma in their own communities is real, says Dr. Sumi Raghavan.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs the feeling that editors are seeking us out, but they‚Äôre not necessarily seeing our experience as the expertise they deserve.‚Äù On our "Covering our Communities" webinar, @amrothom shares the challenges of reporting on anti-Black racism as a Black journalist.

Starting at 3pm EDT: our webinar on how journalists of color can support their mental health while covering traumas within their own communities. Join us live, or follow along here for key takeaways! https://t.co/TgBHVsTocE https://t.co/e4EvKhi0DU

@pressfreedom And: consider the editorial worth of what you‚Äôre doing. If you‚Äôre in significant danger or seeing horrible things, do the risks of reporting outweigh the potential benefits? Assess if the risks are worth it for both your mental and physical health.

From @pressfreedom‚Äôs Colin Pereira: Our society is showing signs of trauma. Do a self-check list before going out to cover protests. Ask: Am I up to this? What‚Äôs been going on around me personally? Results don‚Äôt have to mean not covering, but being more aware of what you need.

#Journalists reporting on protests: Doubling up is key. Having someone to watch your back is invaluable in a shifting situation. Remember: our identities influence our perception of a situation ‚Äì listen if someone on your team feels uncomfortable. @pressfreedom

Should press stand out or blend in? Our security dir. says: when deciding what to wear, think about your location, the time of day you‚Äôre reporting, and the thread of events where you‚Äôre reporting. Do your research and try to remain neutral with your color choices. @pressfreedom

Situational awareness tips from our security director on our webinar with @pressfreedom: Observe the weaponry police forces are armed with. Stay a safe distance away and pay attention to what the police are doing when deciding how close to be to police lines.
@pressfreedom Our list of suggested equipment: https://t.co/1SxCfbsajJ

From our webinar with @pressfreedom, a checklist for journos covering protests. Before you go in, have on:
‚úÖ Loose, sturdy, non-flammable clothes
‚úÖ Mask
‚úÖ Eye protection
‚úÖ Head protection
‚úÖ ID (on a lanyard attached to your clothes!)
‚úÖ Reflective vest
‚úÖ Medical kit

Other tips from @AliBaskerville for #photojournalists covering protests:
-Have a grab bag close to you 
-Pack lightly ‚Äì think versatility over precision
-Clean up your digital presence, including memory cards & photos on your phone
@pressfreedom
"Check that you‚Äôre okay to do this," @AliBaskerville says of covering protests. This work takes a lot of energy, and it's important to take stock of your physical and mental health. @pressfreedom

Key tip @AliBaskerville on our webinar for #journalists covering protests with @pressfreedom: Do your research before heading into a protest. Especially if you‚Äôre not from the area in which you‚Äôre reporting, look at maps and find realistic spots to find safety in an emergency.

When we experience trauma ‚Äì and even after ‚Äì our bodies often exhibit stress reactions. Here are some signs to look for and questions to ask yourself from psychiatrist Kate Porterfield. Check in with what you need and remember: it‚Äôs okay to take a step back. https://t.co/kpZhNt9Ebx

‚ÄúThe concepts of wellbeing and post-traumatic stress need to be part of the fabric of newsrooms. There must be a practice of attending to traumatic stress the way you would respond to other resource needs,‚Äù says trauma expert Kate Porterfield of newsroom response to #COVID19.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very difficult to not be able to touch someone to comfort them. It‚Äôs hard to not have the answers.‚Äù Reporting on pandemics takes a mental toll at some of the most basic levels, says @ClairMacD. It‚Äôs important to keep talking to people & making connections. #COVID19

.@clairmacd‚Äôs experience covering Ebola feels similar to that of reporters covering #COVID19. ‚ÄúI was hesitant to report on Ebola because it was a story that could easily fall into stereotypes. You have to think about reporting sensitively and establish trust with your subjects.‚Äù

A lot of Nadia‚Äôs work has included photographing people in vulnerable situations: ‚ÄúThe key is really to spend time with people, to take the time. It‚Äôs going to pay off.‚Äù At the same time, you have to trust your gut and comfort level when reporting on something like #COVID19. https://t.co/LRQB1ONLmx

Nadia Shira Cohen, a photojournalist covering #COVID19 in Italy, says ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stressful in work mode but it‚Äôs also stressful personally because the ‚Äòenemy‚Äô is so unknown. It‚Äôs very challenging visually to put a face on this while keeping yourself safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúTry not to sensationalize this; don‚Äôt report just for the traffic.‚Äù @Jane_Li911 on the information overload that comes with covering #COVID19 and being careful about what and how you‚Äôre reporting about the virus.

As #COVID19 progressed, Chinese tech reporter @Jane_Li911 found it hard to report on anything other than the virus. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really have a choice ‚Äì every day there are new developments and I have to follow up on them,‚Äù she says during our webinar.

During public health crises, everyone wants 1) a cure and 2) to know the source of the disease. But, @rebecca_kaplan says during our #COVID19 webinar, we need to take a beat before assigning blame to avoid falling into stereotyping or bigotry. https://t.co/8RQ9eMRbiq
